text: I poured it from the bottle into a pint glass. It pours amber with almost no head. The aroma is heavy on caramel with some bread and dark fruit. The taste is caramel, bread, some dark fruit, and earthy. Its a little thin, but the alcohol content is well hidden. This is okay.

Bottle from practically anywhere around here. Amber mostly clear with lasting head and a little lace. Woody earthy toasty caramel brown sugar aroma. Medium-heavy toasted caramelized brown sugar sweetness some mild fruitiness and woody earthy medium-light bitter and pretty dry finish. Medium body, oily. It dries up really nice for what it is, and has a nicely toasted sweetness. Very good.

Wow, cant recall the last time I had a beer from Vermont, also had not previously heard of a "double altbier;" regardless, this is a delicious super-malty brew, pours a rich slightly cloudy amber-brown color, cool caramel and brown sugar malt aroma. Medium-full bodied with a lot of texture, almost chewy like caramel toffee. Flavor is multiple layers of sweet malty and red fruit notes, reminiscent of a doppelbock. Finish is very slightly boozy, with overall a delicious and sweet savory profile. Thoroughly enjoyable!
Bottle from Beers of the World into a pint glass. Little to no carbonation. Aroma is all malt.

While this isnt quite a barn burner, this is a very solid offering from Long Trail and the best beer of theirs that I have tried so far. It pours a nice rosy brown with a thick tan head. The taste is of a malty mouthfeel with chocolatey notes and a bit of a yakky baltic aftertaste. It goes down relatively easy, but sneaks up on you. Never really had an altbier consciously before, but this is basically a mid point between an amber ale and brown ale with a bit more alcoholic kick. Worth a shot if youre in the mood and like dark, malty brews. Otherwise, it is not a tragedy to miss out on this one.

On tap at Valhalla. Pours light clear copper. Hoppy and light bodied for an Alt. However, to manage 7.2% out of a lager is pretty impressive and this beer doesnt tip its hand at all, it tastes really smooth with no off flavors and a clean finish. Good, if unexciting beer.

UPDATED: NOV 2, 2016 Pours almost-clear copper with nearly zero head, just an off-white right. Nice color though. Aroma is slightly malty and just a hint of earthy hop. Flavor is a whole different bag... Delicious waves of malty goodness bread/cracker mixed with a nice dose of caramel. Very slight earthy bitter catches up at the finish, leaving the palate very clean and ready for a another sip. Again, delicious.

On tap at Quarry House Tavern in Silver Spring, MD. 

Clear, copper-orange with a small an off-white head and excellent lacing. 

Aroma of orange, caramel and honey. 

Taste of caramel, wood, orange, honey, alcohol and bitter resin with a bitter rotten fruit aftertaste. Very strange. There is a clash between the basic malt and fruit flavor and the weird aftertaste. 

Medium/full body and medium carbonation with a nice mouthfeel. 

There is much to like in this beer, but nearly as much to dislike. It's a pity about that aftertaste.

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

UPDATED: SEP 28, 2016 Draught. Pours amber with a small off-white head. Aroma is sweet and full of malt with some fruit. Big taste of caramel malt. Some grass and pine towards the end. Bitter finish. Medium body. Medium, fizzy carbonation. Oily, slightly heavy mouthfeel.

Bottle. It pours a deep orange color with a small off white head. The aroma is thick with orange, caramel and honey. Light hints of earthy hops. The flavor is the same. Orange, honey and caramel. Very thick and oily on the palate and sweet for the style. A decent amount of earthy bitterness in the finish. Overall, not bad, but a little too sweet and syrupy for me to rate it high.

A sweet malt aroma with a hint of honey, pours a reddish brown color with a thin short lasting well laced head. An interesting taste, sweet malt hops and a hint of something like lemon grass. A full body with a malt finish.

Bottle, pours a medium amber with a hint of haze and a tan cap. The smell is roasted malt, fruit sweetness, and a touch of brown sugar and herbs. The taste is roasted malt, fruity, crisp hops in the middle ending crisp with a lingering sweetness. Light+ in body with average carbonation. I lived in Düsseldorf for 4 years, this is in the ballpark of a Stikebier but unfortunately doesn't hold up to the originals.
A favorite everyday drinker. Not sure why Ive waited. Bottle poured honey amber, crystal clear. Fine bubbled thin head. Palate is a clean clingy board of malts. Sweet finish lingers. Well done.
On nitro. Deep copper Amber with thick foamy lacy beige head; grainy malty; flava is malty grainy nutty tangy; feels light; finishes grassy bitter

Bottle. Pours a bit copper and a bit cloudy. Slight floral aroma. Big malt up front but a strong boozy flavor that I didnt enjoy. Some heat at the back end so no hiding the higher ABV. I really like their regular alt and think Ill stick to that.

Smells of caramel malt orange zest with a slight rotted grape of wine smell. Color is a orange and gold color. Taste as sweet from the mounts bitterness coming through slightly fall by Boozy aftertaste. Medium body smooth Crisp carbonation. Not a bad brew just dont care for the winey finish or the alcohol burn.

Nitro. Amber, creamy head. 
Medium body, slight in flavor and heat, fairly long palate and tasty finish. 
Moderately bitter, off-dry. 
Resiny, hoppy, malty. 
Delicate, light, pleasant.

If youre looking to stick every rating here on at least one beer, this fits the just-above-the-middle-of-the-road rating. Its got a bitter aftertaste that takes away from the initial taste, but not so bitter that it runs it. Its...just above average.

Bottle. Pours a clear dark amber with a bubbly white head that fades. Aroma of oak, malt, hops, a hint of sweeter fruit. Taste has a lot of crisp yeasty malt, with an underlying sweetness and wood. Hides the alcohol. Lingering crispness that isnt very big. Drinkable, not bad.

En fût. Pinte dégustée directement à la brasserie au coût de 5,00$. Arôme: Odeur de caramel avec une pointe de fruitée. Apparence: La couleur est ambrée foncée avec une faible densité de bulle. Présence dun mince col mousseux et dune fine dentelle sur le verre. Saveur: Goût de caramel avec une pointe de céréales et de bananes. Durée moyenne de larrière goût. Palette: Le corps est moyen avec une texture légèrement onctueuse. Moyenne effervescence en bouche. Légère présence de caramel en arrière goût. (Rating #6526)

12 oz bottle poured dark amber into a pint glass, with minimal white head. Aromas of berries and floral malt. Taste initially of a little booze then quickly turns to a roasted caramel with a smooth sweet aftertaste. Pretty solid beer, can have several of these in one sitting.

12 oz. bottle. Pours a clear deep amber with a small white head and moderate lacing. Caramel and rye in the nose. Mild bitterness in the taste. Medium-bodied. Lively carbonation. Nice brew.

Pours a dark amber from a bottle, not much nose, although served rather cold so maybe just much wasnt making it out of the glass. Flavor a nice caramel yeastiness, some banana/tropical fruit notes. Good beer.
Pours a clear amber. A malty and caramel aroma. A sweet malty taste with dark fruits, caramel, and light grains. A decent malty aftertaste.

Bottle poured a clear amber with a small lingering amber head. Aromas of toasted malt, caramel and earthiness. Palate was light bodied and smooth with a dry finish. Flavors of caramel and toasted malt with a smooth dry finish.

Draught @ Waterfront Ale House. Slightly cloudy dark amber with small foamy beige head, faint caramel aroma, low carbonation, lightly bitter hoppy caramel taste, longish finish. Not too bitter and nice.

650ml bottle. Picked this local beer up while passing through Vermont. Pour yields good lacing, and a beer that has copper/caramel and amber hues. Persistent carbonation keeps thin ring around glass and offers up constant aromas of dried fruit, roasted nuts and melted brown sugar. On the palate, the malt shows through. Subtle sweetness gives way to slight bitterness. Initially a little boozy, but that too is easy to forgive given the 7.2%abv. Overall, a fine effort. Hope to try more from long Trail

Bottle. Aroma is sweet malts with floral contributions. Appearance is clear dark brown with nice sparkle, and decent head. Taste is moderately sweet with sugary maltiness and mild fruit and hint of alcohol. Palate is medium bodied with lively carbonation and nice sweet finish. Overall, a nice beer without a lot of complexity.

Very good
Bottle. Aroma is boozy with some marshmallow and grape. Fruit punch taste with a bitter and slightly boozy finish.

Sample at Daily Growler UA. Clear copper color with a medium white head that recedes steadily. Stringy lacing on the glass. Aroma of malt, toffee and hops. Medium body with flavors of caramel malt, earthy hops and a bit of fruit. The finish is sweet with a malty aftertaste. Slightly above average overall.

12 Fl. Oz. Bottle. Poured clear, reddish amber in color, small off white head and little bit of spotty lacing. Aroma of roasted malts and fruits. Taste of nuts, roasted malts and caramel, booze was well hidden. Nice beer, easy to drink.

Pours nicely - transparent copper w/ a lasting tan head & lovely lacing. The aroma is predominantly malfy & a tad sweet. The taste is quite malfy w/ a bit of a bitter kick in the finish. The body is very light & pleasant on the palate. Overall this is a solid beer!

Bottle. Pours clear brown with a creamy white mostly lasting head that leaves good lacing. Aroma of brown sugar and caramel. Mouthfeel of fine bubbles and soft carbo, lightly sweet, medium bitter, light body and a brief bitter and sweet finish.
Tap. Copper pour with a big white head. Brown sugar, herb, and bread. Medium body. Nice but does not feel the 7.2%
On draft at Justins. Appearance is medium amber. Aroma is rich, malty and notes of alcohol. Tastes quite nice, a rich, soft and not too sweet. Palate was thin. Overall pretty good beer.

Not quite on point for style. Lacks the interesting malt crispness and profile. Instead the malt comes off on the sweet side here lots of caramel and sugar. Pours brown with OK head and lacing. Bottle.

UPDATED: AUG 28, 2015 Appealing dark amber color. Toasted malt with a trace of grape(brandy comes to mind).  Smoky, not overly sweet with a just enough hop bitterness for a clean finish.  I dont always drink Altbier,  but when I do, its Double Bag.  This has become one of my all time favorites.
bottle poured into a tumbler..amber/orange with a fluffy white head..aroma of caramel,malts...dry,malty,sweet..not bad.

Clear copper with tan head. Aroma is dry caramel malt with hints of yeast. Flavor is toffee caramel, medium bittering. Paired nicely with chocolate cake. This is the first Long Trail beer I have ever bought but not the first I have enjoyed thanks to the mayor of long trail.

Aroma bread, cereal, 
Appearance amber, clear, frothy, white foam, 
Taste light sweetness, lightly bitter, 
Palate medium body, average carbonation, 
Overall an average beer that I would suggest to a friend
12 ounce bottle.copper color with a bubbly beige head. Roasty malt nose. Bittersweet toasted malt flavor. Smooth and spicy with a pleasant herbal hop backdrop. Toasted nut finish.

Had this on draft at the brewery and loved it. When I bought the 12 pack, it was much more hop forward than the draft. This was one my wife liked on draft, but not in the bottle. Tastes better after it sits open. Still has lingering cascade hop flavor.

From 12 oz bottle, variety pack

Aroma: Sweet, caramel, toffee, malty

Appearance: Amber, Clear liquid, tan head

Taste: Heavy sweetness but not in bad way, light bitterness

Palate: Medium body. Good carbonation. Slight bitter finish

Overall: I have had a lot of Altbiers other than Long Trail, but this is a nice one. A bit sweet and malty, but no cloyiness. Very clean. Very easy to drink. Highly digestible. Pretty good beer to have with food. Alcohol is well masked, hard to detect that its 7%.

amber with a slight haze, cappuccino head that is fast to fade to a frothy ring. Aroma is touch of caramel, grassy lager flavor with a hint of blackberry. Body is watery-syrupy, medium weight with a delayed, medium-fine carbonation, medium-light intensity. Small burn. Flavor is sweet berry hard candy, lemongrass, and a light phenolic resin bitterness in the finish. Some caramel in the finish as it warms.   A very nice alt, a bit syrupy in flavor and body - could use more dry malt character and a more present aroma.  No serious flaws and a nice subtle berry contribution from the yeast, despite the cool fermentation.
Lots of malt, and lots of alcohol. Thats about it, not much more to be said.

bottle. clear copper with a small off-white head. malty aroma with hints of crystal malt. malty, nutty, toasty melanoidin rich flavors from something like munich malt and mid color crystal with crackery base malt. light alcohol warmth and a lingering bitter/floral finish. medium bodied. its a well rounded beer, very nice for what it is. im surprised at the popularity of this brew as a flagship, its actually inspiring, considering its not a hop forward ipa or something of that nature.

Bottle. Murky brown. Sweet malt, caramel, rye, bread crust and toast. Low carb, medium richness. A touch of bitterness. Good stuff.

Purchased from Cigarette City earlier today. $7.99 for the 6pack. To oversized snifter, it pours an effervescent skin-tinted light maroon with which an eggshell white ringed head 1 finger in length stood. Aromas of Vienna malt/nuttiness/cashew butter, banana peppers, dried seaweed, German noble hops, Bavaria (lager) yeast, lime meat, basil, DME, and earl grey tea. Tastes the same with the addition of biscuit malt, avocados, salted butter, and wet cardboard. Sweat, plastic, and sourdough cultures experienced by swallow. Likeable modern take on a very elusive German style.

Nice beer, very nice color and taste, a little sweet but a good malt taste and no aftertaste, nice ABV and smooth, easy to have several

Taste is more of the same, slightly sweet dark fruits balanced with the pine hops on the back end. Medium body, smooth finish, great beer and probably their best (except for Limbo of course :) )

Enjoyed in Vermont. Pours a caramel colour with a light beige head and very nice sticky lacing. Dark fruit aromas. Floral perfume taste with fruity malts. Altbier malts eventually comes out in the finish. Quite smooth mouthfeel and a nice brew overall.

12oz bottle pours a murky amber/brown with no head. Aroma is slightly floral with a dry caramel malt. Taste of upfront sweet caramel and toffee floral hops and then the flavor just drops off into nothing. Not bad.
Red amber pour. Aroma creamy and citrus. Tastes caramel, pine, like a tart woody scotch ale. Creamy palate.  classic.  smooth.  high abv.

DATE REVIEWED: August 23, 2014... GLASSWARE: Hobgobin stange... OCCASION: Lord of the Rings return to school prep... APPEARANCE: stately brown/orange body; strong, two-finger off-white head; spongy at first, sinewy as it clings to the glass; handsome... AROMA: surprisingly fragrant bouquet from an alt; blanketing caramel malts; some wet leaf and earthy tones... PALATE: heavy, full-bodied and long in its aftertaste; soft hops play at the teeth; palpable yet palatable ... TASTE: vibrant toffee and toast make this a brown with bite; the earthy malts make a course, somewhat complex sip; hops are floral and complimentary ... OVERALL: a Long Trail brew to get behind--a malty ale that brings the weight of 7.2 % ABV subtly; powerful and energizing...

355ml bottle. Very malty and strong. A good American knock off of a German doppel alt. Recommended.

Poured from a growler into a pint

Appearance  The beer pours an amber color with a two finger off white head. The head fades over a moderate level of time to give a decent level of lacing. 

Smell  The aroma is bready and malty with some notes of caramel and some herbal hop. 

Taste  The taste begins with a lightly roasted and bready taste. Upfront there is a caramel taste that melds with the bready tastes well. Soon some bitter grapefruit and lemon hop flavors come to the tongue. Shortly after arriving these flavors seem to lose their strength. As the lemon and grapefruit dwindle a bitter herbal flavor comes to the tongue. This herbal flavor intensifies to the end where they combined with a light alcohol flavor to leave a malty and lightly bittered flavor on the tongue.

Mouthfeel  The mouthfeel is on the rather average side, but kind of thin for a 7.2 % abv brew. Its carbonation level was moderate and rather appropriate for the style.

Overall  It was a decent brew. It had some good malty flavors and a light herbal hop. Worth a try, but nothing that is super exceptional. A decent stronger Alt. style ale.
pours brown clear without head or lacing. acidic brown sugar aroma. taste is malt dominated with a bit of lemon bite later. finish is damp and slightly bitter. Meh.
Light brown with a nice off white foam. Sweet malt aroma and sticky caramel and bread flavors. Malty finish is quite pleasant.
Bottle. Amber colour. Malty caramel aroma. Flavour is malty, caramel, toffee
Pours Amber with a thin off white head. Aroma of sweet and malt. Flavor is a mix of earthy and malty.
12 oz bottle pours amber with a off white head. Aroma of malts, caramel and toffee. Taste is malts, toffee and some biscuit.

Bottle from Harvest Market
Pours a fairly clear medium amber color with a smallish off white head that dissipates fairly quickly. Aromas of caramel toffee and brown sugar with just a hint of butterscotch. Earthy bitterness in the aroma keeps this in check. The flavor is sweet rich sugars with some melanoids and a bit of burnt sneaking in there. Earthy bitterness with a touch of burnt butter round us out. Medium body with a moderate level of carbonation. There is a bit of diacetyl here and that usually turns me off to a beer, but this is one of the rare instances where I think it works within the frame of the rest of the brew.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz. bottle into a pint glass.

Appearance: It had a deep copper color with visible carbonation and nice clarity. The head was thin, light tan in color and faded fast leaving spotty bubbles on top of the liquid. A small amount of lace was left on the glass.

Smell: The aroma had a sweet malty character with caramel notes and mild hops.

Taste/Mouth feel: On the tongue there is a thick sweet malt presence with sweet biscuit and caramel notes. The sweetness is balanced nicely by a strong herbal and leafy hops that seems to take over by the finish. The finish is slow and the flavor seems to stick on the tongue. It has a medium body with a creamy smooth texture and carbonation is active yet very mild.

Notes: It is a strong beer with bold flavor. Very well done!

UPDATED: MAR 8, 2016 Pours clear copper with thin tan head. Nose is malty. Aromas are malt, caramel, herbal hops, with a metalic aftertaste. Medium carbonation, medium body. Medium bitter and metallic finish.
Drank from bottle, malty aroma with some hoppiness. Malty flavor, very slight hop flavor.
BBOTMC. Pours red with a nice head, aroma of toffee, caramel, cookies, alcohol, flavor of caramel, cookies, slightly bitter with herbal tones, medium bodied.

12 oz bottle into a pint glass.

A: Pours a clear copper color. The head is a one finger off-white shade, and while its relatively creamy looking, it doesnt have the best retention.

S: The malt is typically toffee-forward, but with that faint German touch to it. Namely, stone fruits and just a hint of diacetyl. Theres a hop profile thats very mellow yet still noticeable. Not bad, not bad at all.

T: Loads of toffee start this one off. The flavor even gets faintly nutty at times, with some nice apricot notes right after the swallow. There does seem to be a touch of alcohol flavor (along with a faint burn) on the finish. I have to say that overall, the flavor profile isnt my cup of tea.

M: Its actually kind of coarse, and even slightly angular in feel. This helps to give it pretty good drinkability in spite of its maltiness. Carbonation is light, which somehow suits this one.

O: This isnt my (double) bag, as the scores reflect. Still, I dont hate it. Decent to try if youre looking for something different, but I wouldnt recommend a full 6 pack.
Bottle, aroma is rich sweet malt with a touch of pine hops. Taste is nice toasted malt sweetness with a semi sweet finish.

Bottle. Pours clear dark gold with a 1 finger white head. Aroma is slightly metallic, fruity esters and caramel. Taste adds some toffee and spice with a moderate alcohol punch. Bready malt and fruity notes make appearances as it warms. Medium sticky smooth palate with light carbonation. Pretty nice.

Great balance and full bodied flavor and at 7.2 this is always a solid go to... Great work longtrail!

The smell is malty and slightly fruity with some nuts that try to carry over slightly. The taste is a rich and well balanced malty fruitiness. On the palate its about a medium in body, comes across fairly sessionable, no aftertaste with a dry earthy finish, slightly crisp. Overall, this is a good beer for its style and good to me
4/11/2011. From bottle. Amber color with a white head. Sweet caramel aromas with light fruit and a bit of earthy notes. Caramel flavors mostly with little hops on the finish as expected.

Bottle from the corner shop at NY Tribeca
Clear deep amber color, small white creamy head. Caramel and rye in the nose. Medium-bodied. Caramelly-caramalt, low bitterness. Clean amber ale.

This beer seemed so extreme 10 years ago... not so much anymore, but it still holds up well. Long Trail has their own niche because, for some reason, craft brewers havent really embraced the altbier style. This is a fairly straightforward malty beer, without any cloying sweetness. Bottle from Wegmans, Pours clear copper with no head to speak of. The aroma is quite malty, some caramel, molasses, a bit sweet. The taste is sweet caramel, honey, a bit of a slight smokiness. Not overly weet but this does not stand up to the best in the style.

Pours a clear orange brown. Aroma of honey and syrup. Taste is malty up front followed by a stiff bitterness. Then a crisp finish with a lingering honey flavor.

Bottle, BBOTM Club. Cloudy reddish brown. Spicy aroma - pears cooked with red wine and cinnamon, plum. alcoholic, a little spicy, a little sweet taste. Full body, biscuity undertones and alcohol.

Tap into pint. Light brown, thin white head. Sweet almost sugary nose. Sweet in the mouth notes of maple and heavy malt. Light hops. Finished clean, moderate length with lingering malt. Modestly heavy in the mouth but goes down easy. Nice fall drinker.

The appearance is a nice light amber color with an off white head. The beer is well carbonated and has some lacing that will last for a while. The smell is a nice malty, sweet caramel scent at first but gives away to a mild chocolate smell. Deep amber color with a beige colored head. Caramel malts, nutty, dank hops, overall sweet aroma. Good, but I think this might be an old bottle. Would like to try it fresh!

A reddish orange with miniscule off white head. Aroma is fruity with toffee and malt. Medium body. Flavor at first is sweet and dominated by caramel malt. Then an herbal hop presence with rather dry finish. Interesting but very drinkable. Just grabbed this a part of a mixed 6 pack at the supermarket, and have to say its surprisingly good.
Has strong malt aroma. Thick tasting with nice aftertaste. No head. Nice dark amber color. Good malt taste. Comparable to a strong wheat beer. Really enjoyed it.

Chimay Grand Reserve is far-and-away my all-time favorite, but I savor it only on special occasions. Second all-time fave is/was Sam Adams seasonal Double Bock, but they havent made it available consistently like they used to before the company went public. So-o-o-o, LT DB has become my goto brew since then. Its almost as tasty as the SA DB, its got similar high alcohol content, but its also cheaper, and widely available all year round.

Clear medium amber - great color - long lasting head cover, hanging streams of lace. Perfect balance of caramel malt, light bitters, and a touch of hay and biscuit. As easy to drink as this is, it makes sense the brewer warns against overindulging. I visited Maine in late June, bought back 100 bottles of beer thats not available in Cincinnati, but only two bottles of the Double Bag - what a mistake!

On vacation in Vermont, picked up a few six packs of local brews with Double Bag among them. Pours a slightly cloudy amber, head dissipates quickly, no lacing on the glass. A fruity, malty and inviting aroma, tempting one to take a sip. Toasty, caramel, enough bitterness to balance it out resulting in a malty-yet-crisp brew. Tastes lighter than it really is.

Sample as part of a flight at Mews Tavern on 7/3/13. Clear amber pour with a medium tan head. Aroma of malt, caramel, rum and raisins. Malty and caramelly flavor with some fruit before a semi-dry noble hop finish.

12 oz bottle. Pours medium amber, fast fading off-white head, not a whole lot of lacing. Smell is caramel dark fruit, a bit of bread, faint hops a bit of roastiness. Taste is semi sweet, caramel, earthy malt, nice bitterness from the malt, a bit of alcohol. Mouthfeel is syrupy yet bubbly. Texture reminds me a bit if a dunkel. text: Great tasting beer, suprisingly smooth for a 7.2 alcohol content, deff not a session beer. Pours deep amber, nice head, malty with great finish
Nice apple aroma and flavor. Nice nuttiness as well. A bit sweet, but to be expected for a high gravity "alt."

What a wonderful brew. A higher alcohol altbier, but doesnt taste that way. Quite sweet, wheat and caramel-like entry, a (very) slight bitterness and then an extremely smooth finish with creamy, bready notes. Beautiful cloudy amber, creamy and luxurious mouthfeel. A very underrated beer that deserves the praise it receives here.
Light malty aroma. Nice ruby appearance. Good flavor of malt and fruit. Mouthfeel is average.

Aroma is malt forward. There is lots of caramel and toasted bread. Along with those is some fruitiness associated with the malt - cherry, raisin and prune. No real hop aroma. Light chocolate character. Faint alcohol note as it warms. 
Pours a slightly cloudy copper red to orange with a thin slightly off white head that recedes quickly to the edges. 
Flavor is also very malt forward but with a hint of hop character. Malt is darker than the aroma suggested. Lots of toasted bread bordering on burnt. Some caramel, toffee and light chocolate as well. Lots of dark fruit including cherry, prune and plum. There is a moderate noble hop character as well as a moderate bitterness. Light alcohol spice in the finish. 
Mouthfeel is medium full bodied with medium low carbonation. Low astringency and medium low alcohol heat. 
Overall a nice malty German style beer. Very clean fermentation allows for the malt to really dominate the flavor. Medium low hop notes balance the malt and keep the beer from being too sweet.

A - Pours a dark amber red. 1 finger off-white head that melts down into a thin ceiling and forming a tight collar.

S - Graham cracker, toffee, yeast, over ripened plums, brown sugar, roasted caramel malt.

T - Sweet caramel/toffee up front and quickly turns complex with raisins, ginger, toasted nuts, and soft grain. More hops in the flavor than the nose reveals and creates some spice in the back of the mouth. Everything comes together like a symphony at the end. Excellent finish!

M - Low carbonation. Medium to full bodied.

Long Trail has a winner here! Lots of complex fruit esters melded with an excellent malt profile. I wish I would have picked up a six pack of his stuff.

12-03-2010

Aroma of dark berry and toasted malt, and also features perceptible alcohol. Intense copper color. Taste of dry fruits and nuts and sweet booze. Very smooth, but pulls no punches with its strength. From a 12 oz bottle at Jakes on Main in Danville VA.  Pours a hazy amber with an off white head.  Mild malty aroma. Flavors of caramel with nice hops.
On draft.  Taste is a nice blend of booze, caramel, malt and hay.  Very enjoyable.
A dark brown hue with a white head. Malty and deep with a mix of bright notes. The finish is clean and the is balanced quite well. I have been quite pleased with Longtrail overall.

Very good beer.  Pour is a dark amber. with a thin head. Aroma is soft and not over powering.  Earthy notes and hints of flowers.  Tastes of caramel with a mild and easy bitterness at there finish.  Well done overall.
Nice head, simple, beautiful color. A little boozier than I was expecting. Taste has the bitter coffee-like finish that another reviewer noted. A nice fruity ( maybe cherries?) taste, too.

Smooth and malty with a sweet and hoppy finish. Little carbonation. A decent brew.

Smooth, malty flavor with a subtly sweet and hoppy finish. A beer that is growing on me.

Une bouteille achetée par Patrick au Vermont. Bière cuivrée pâle avec une mousse crémeuse beige. Le nez est discret, lactique et houblonné. La bouche est mordante, amère, simple et efficace. Correct 6/10

Awesome commercial Sticke.  Ive wanted to try this for years now.  Finally on the east coast in DC, and I grabbed a sixer of this from the Foggy Bottom Whole Foods.  Malty, fruity smelling - good balance of hops.  I enjoy this quite a bit.
Aroma is fruit, malts and a hint of nuttiness.  The flavor is nutty/slightly dry malts, fruit, mild/medium sweetness and a smooth/slightly fruity finish.

Tap at Rocket Bar. Clear cherry ruby pour. Medium off white head. Layered lacing. Nose is sweet cherry juice and freezer vegetables. Taste is oil, freezer vegetables, cherry juice box. Eh.

Draft pours like a red brown not bad head. Smells of malt booze spice roasty. Its an ok beer kind of bitter. Flavors work just not my thing.

Tap/Growler. Clear amber color. Fluffy white head. Beautiful aroma of floral hops, wheaty malts, and sweet molasses. Flavor was hop bitterness and character rounded by wheaty malts with a touch of brown sugar and toasty malts. Wonderful palate, great overall.

pours light coppery-orange with a small white cap, no retention. citrusy, tanginess, light acidity, light dry caramel malts, toffee-biscuity, a lot of herbs too. soft carbonation, medium body, silky, short to medium long herbal-citrusy finish

Somewhat low in effervescence on the palate, body is medium-full.  Enjoyable, although I might personally find a sixer a little hard to finish single-handedly in a reasonable amount of time.

OK, I admit it.  I thought (assumed, like an ass) this was a IIPA when I drank it.  Im like, "Wow, this is a really malt, balanced, not too hoppy IIPA."  Wellllllll, I guess I was wrong. 12oz - Good, solid ale, meets the description of the style.  With the malty back its a good Fall selection.

355 ml bottle purchased at the brewery, on July 27, 2011. Light amber, thin head. Aroma of malted barley sweetness, notes of spicy nuts. Raw malted barley taste, bitter nutty notes, aftertaste of alcohol. A simple but nice Alt!

most altbieren.

If you know me you know I prefer a hoppy beer to a malty one, but you should also know that I appreciate a tasty beer no matter which way it leans. Long Trail Double Bag is one of the maltiest beers Ive ever encountered and yet I found it very delectable. POUR, COLOR AND AROMAThe beer pours smoothly to a clear, dark amber color which is almost a shade of brown proper. The head is average-sized, off-white, and foamy. It dissolves rather quickly, but it does leave a little lacing on the glass. The scent is a strong mixture of malt, caramel and what I would call an autumn-like aroma of wet leaves and pumpkin [Im quite sure its made with neither!]TASTEI hate it when its not clear what style a beer belongs to since it makes it a bit more difficult to prepare my frame of reference. Long Trails website describes Double Bag as a Strong Dark Ale but the label says its a stickebier which is basically a strong altbier. Whatever the case may be, the fact remains this beer does seem to have some very Germanic roots.Upon taking my first taste the flavors of caramel, chocolate and toffee were immediately noticeable. I also noticed a light, but seeming varied palate of spices such as nutmeg and cinnamon. Taking all these flavors into consideration, its no wonder this beer reminded me so much of an Oktoberfest brew even though its of a completely different style.Regardless, the fact remains Double Bag is quite a tasty beer. Its sweet and sticky not unlike the Long Trail Ale, only with a richer, smoother flavor. There is no bitterness or dryness to the flavor here, just a strong, non-threatening, array of sweetness and taste.FINISHThe label says, The secret is that this brew is so smooth, youd never believe it has an alcohol content of 7.2!!! [sic]. When I read that I scoffed at the notion, but after a few swigs I found a truthiness in it. The alcohol is masked very well and is only noticeable in the finish. Otherwise, Double Bag has a thick, but extremely gentle mouthfeel that coats the entire mouth in flavor. For such an otherwise strong ale its amazing how drinker-friendly this beer really is.BODYFollowing the note on the beers smoothness, the label also advises, INDULGE IN MODERATION!!!!!! [sic]. I could see why they would make such a disclaimer since the taste and drinkability are so good that the icing on the cake is the surprising absence of a heavy body. Although I only drank one bottle of this beer, I didnt feel as if I had drunk anything at all. This is a session beer in disguise.FINAL THOUGHTSI have to admit I wasnt expecting much from a beer with a picture of two cows on the label (what IS the deal with that, anyway?). Still, Long Trail Double Bag was one of the nicer surprises in my beer-drinking experience and I wish I had more to appreciate. This would make a great inclusion in one of their mix packs since its superior to their otherwise average line of brews. An amber color with a balanced flavor. Not too hoppy nor malty, it is rich in taste. A rather decent altbier.

M: Medium-bodied and creamy, with soft-to-average carbonation.

The flavor is malty yet somehow very dry. Nutty with hints of cherry and spice and a bitterness that reaches all the way down the esophagus. Interesting.

A grassy, hoppy flavor with a lingering bitterness - not bad balance.  Goes down smooth with well-masked alcohol.  Nothing special about this beer, but I found it pleasant enough.
Bottle.  Pours brown with an off-white head.  Aroma is nutty and sweet.  Flavor is nutty and malty.  Doesnt taste like 7.2 ABV.

[bottle]
Nice creamy aroma with toffee and gentle noble hops and dried apricot  and lychee notes. Clear orange-amber under white wisps. Medium body, moderate to medium bitterness, slightly bitter nutty finish, moderate to medium carbonation.
bottle. Poured a brown color with a medium off white head. Aroma of sweet candy and some mild hops. The taste is somewhat dissappointing. Not very balanced. Quite thin on the palate. Ehh

i always tell myself to eat a meal before a 6 of these because they usually kick my ass. i dont know why, there is just something about it that always does it to me. Lots of malty, caramel and toffee-esque taste going on here. goes down easy saying that and its pretty strong and sneaks up on you quick. nothing special but never count it out.

Another in my east coast beer tasting odyssey.  This 12 oz bottle, from a six pack poured a dark garnet color, with an off-white head and good rich lacing rings. Nose of caramel malts and ripe fruit. Pours a three finger cream head that fades to a thin layer leaving some lace. Nice crystal clear amber color. Light carbonation and medium bodied.  Slight malty nose. Flavor is sweet malty but finishes with some bitterness. $1.65 for a 12oz bottle from Colonial Spirits Acton, MA.

Thanks to Emerson I am able to indulge and I mean indulge myself here with this fine specimen. Pours thick and juicy with no head. Mild aromatically but does smell like beer. Full rich and malty, hey did I say that ? Superb effers. Theres a defined hop essence snickering in the corner balancing this bad boy out. Freakin great beer. Nice and dry despite the caramel malt infusion. Thanks man!
12 oz bottle... dark goldish pour... small head... smells a little metallic... hops and malt blend is nice... surprisingly easy to drink for alcohol content... a good one.

bottle.. hazy deep copper pour,thin off white head ,some lacing. aroma is sweet and fruity.sweet caramel malt flavors upfront also some toffee.some nice resiny hops in the finish,dry.medium bodied and carbonation .

22oz. Pour is amber with a lacy slight off white head. Aromas of citrus fruit, piney hops, caramel, and sweet malts. Flavor is crisp with resin, sweet malts, and finishing somewhat dry and hoppy. The 7.3abv is hidden well. Nice brew.
user_location: back in NJ!, New Jersey, USA

text: Bottle. Poured a hazy dark orange color with a thin off white head. So so aroma that included the likes of graham, tart peach, and a bit of apricot. Light to medium bodied and delicately sweet. Fruitier than I had expected. Dark fruits mostly. There was also a bit of toffee. So so.

Bottle from Brattleboro Food Coop. Amber orange body with rocky white head. Hoppy nose. Quite strong taste, of caramel, malts. So pretty sweetish then nice hops in the finish. High ABV in the finish as well.

Long Trail event at the Golden Rail.  Pours a golden brown amber with a thin white head.  Touch of smoke and toasted malt.  Flavor is slightly sweet with a touch of caramel and malt.  Finishes a little sweet with a light grain flavor and more malt with a nice light bitter.

Bottle.  Pours clear amber with a small, fizzy, white head, mostly diminishing with good lacing.  Aroma is heavy malt (cookie, caramel, toasted grain, nutty), light hops (perfume), heavy yeast (earth, leaves, broth) with notes of prune, dates, and brown sugar.  Medium bodied, sticky texture, lively carbonation, and a bitter finish.  Average duration, moderate sweetness, acidity, and bitterness.
Draft.  Pours a deep browned color with some decent malts and a nice hops kick.

Enjoyed from a 12oz bottle.  Pours a deep brown color.  Nose is of Munich and other German character malts.  This beer is full on the palate, tasting of the aforementioned malts, with a long, sweet finish that is malty without being cloying.  Overall, a well done strong alt.
Draft and bottles. Multiple tastings. (previous tastings from memory) Tasted this as part of a sampler at the brewpub. Remembered this to be one of the better ones in the group.
I dont even get it.  The bar next to CBC says its a double IPA, which I knew immediately was a shameful description.  Amateur nose, rosey ASA body with no lasting finish.

Bottle courtesy of dogfish120love.  Pours a dark clear amber with a 2 finger beige head that results in delicate lacing.  The nose is heavy caramel malt and earthy hops.  The taste is caramel and toasted toffee with a nice resin finish.  Medium mouth feel.  Good beer.  Thanks Brian!

Not overly complicated, but nice.  Alcohol very well hidden.  Not much of an aroma at all.  A bit buttery and nutty flavor, with a definite german lager taste at the back of the throat...NOT a hoppy back-of-the-tongue bitternes at all.  It actually cut through the vinegar in the saurkraut I was eating pretty well.

Bottle in trade from ROBORB.  Thanks man!  Pours a clear amber with short lived cream colored head.  Smell is an interesting sweet maltiness that comes across like it will be nutty, and overly sweet perhaps.  Taste is more balanced than the nose would indicate, but still leaning malty with an interesting sticky sweetness to the flavor, a mild dosing of floral hops to balance in the middle and then it finishes with caramel like malt and doesnt leave a sweet aftertaste.  Tastes much better than it smells, and is really a nice, enjoyable beer.  Medium body and carbonation and no presence of alcohol in the flavor.

12oz

Received this is a recent trade with israel, thanks again! Long Trails Double Bag fills the glass a perfectly clear amber with orange highlights throughout the glass. Carbonation rises from all over the bottom of the glass. The off white head grew to two fingers on the pour and after a few drinks settled to a solid cap leaving chunky lace lines behind. This is a very good looking beer.

The first thing thats hits me in the aroma is the nuttiness from the malt. Theres a touch of floral hoppiness floating around in the background and a nice addition of caramel throughout that adds to the nuttiness. Theres a ghost like alcohol presence just sort of gliding through here and there.

The flavor follows the aroma fairly closely. A malt driven caramel and nuttiness lead the way allowing the floral hoppiness to rise and fall throughout. The hops even show a touch of citrus on the tongue. The alcohol is a little more pronounced in the flavor then the nose suggested but overall this is a good beer.

The mouthfeel of this beer is the standout point. Double Bag is luxuriously rich and creamy right off the bat. The body slides through without a problem. The only thing keeping this from getting a 5 is that it seems to get a little light in the back of the throat and a little heat is present.

This is an easy enough beer to drink. Its a good beer but just seems a little dull. I would happily drink a few in a sitting but the abv could catch up rather easy after a couple more.

This is a solid alt from Long Trail. Although alts really arent something I drink all that often this was an enjoyable beer. I wouldnt mind giving this another try if I had a couple more. Thanks again Israel.

6/26/08

12oz bottle.  Pours a cloudy, amber body with no significant white head and minimal lacing.  Has a sweet, robust, malty smell with some bitter and alcohol notes.  Has a pretty robust, malty taste with some nice toffee notes and a slight bitterness to the beer overall that was complimenting of the sweet malts.  A medium bodied, fairly smooth mouthfeel that was pretty nice on the palate.  A nice mouthfeel and taste combination made this beer very drinkable and good overall.

UPDATED: AUG 16, 2011 In short: A big Altbier.  Big and sweet for the style but still very drinkable.  Enjoyable.
How: Bottle 22oz
The look: Clear redish-coppper body topped by a very small off-white head
In long: Nose of sweet red fruits, candies, crème-caramel and aromatic flowers.  Body is rather full and carbonation is comfortably relaxed.  A lot of dried fruits, citrus, some hard-candies and quite a bit of smooth caramel.  A hefty dose of floral hops really juice up the beer and distracts from the sweetness.  Very clean.  Really nice how the fruity sweetness and floral juiciness blend in nicely.  Probably the best Long Trail Ive had.  If all long trails would be that nice Americans would look like those we see on the tv shows and wouldnt be so fat after all that hiking
Interesting, but very buttery aroma. Tastes oxidized and weird. Some nice sweetness with a good hop backbone, but I dont think Id have another.

Bottle thanks to jah noth.  Pours amber in color with a quickly diminishing white head.  Aromas of sweet malts, caramel, vanilla, and some fruit notes.  Flavors up front are sweet malts, also a bit fruity.  Finish is moderately hoppy and bitter.

A nice and smooth, strong brew.  Has hints of malts and hops.  Nice dark gold/light brown color.  Tastes of of smooth malts with very light hops.  Not too much carbonation in this brew which is a very pleasant attribute.  Has a nice easy and smooth aftertaste.  This is great brew from Long Trail.  Good job guys.

POured a dark amvber to brown color with an off white head. Aroma was really malty and caramel with notes of alcohol. Flavor was also very malty not much hops here at all, hints of metallic and alcohol flavor that is hard to get over.
Pours amber with a thick off white head. Caramel malt molasses and a hint of hop aroma. Nice malty body with a good earthy hop bitterness. Solid version of an Alt.

Pours golden with a nicly lacing head that disappears quick.
Good hoppy / alcohol flavor with some kick to boot.
Bottle Pours an amber body with a thin off white head.  Lots of earthy hop body with a caramel malt body and and brown sugar.  Light citrus and pine qualities.  Good brew.
Fruity, too fruity aroma.  Clear bright orange-red.  Bad label.  Meh.  Tangy, medium astringency, fruit, slightly medicinal.  Not inspiring.

Sampled from a 12 oz brown bottle this beer poured a caramel-amber color with a small tan head. The aroma was sweet, malty and had a touch of chocolate and malted milk. The flavor was sweet, creamy, malted milt and a touch of caramel and chocolate. There was a lightly tangy malt undertone and a malty tangy finish. The body was nicely thick and very smooth. Nice.

Amber brown color with big white head.  An extreme flurry of carbonation makes this a lively looking ale.  The aroma contains a cornucopia of scents.  Orange and peach come out first then maybe strawberry.  After the fruit a medium roast malt sets a base and light hops finish for the full ride. The taste is full malted with slight fruit notes and a caramel finish.  Palate is remarkably light considering the amount of malt and the alcohol content.  This is a surprising yet hard to describe beer.  Most amazing is how it contains a relatively high alcohol (7.2%) but still shows so many vast flavors.
12 oz. bottle. Pours a nice burnt orange. Taste is filled with hops but there is not much of an aroma to it. This is a full bodied, slightly bitter beer.

12 ounce bottle shared with and courtesy of Alraomon. Thanks Sean! Pours a clear orange-red color with a thin white head. The aroma was somewhat weak, but did come across as earthy and hoppy. Taste is filled with noble hops with caramel and grainy notes. Very bitter, but it sneaks up in a very pleasant way. Full bodied. Highly drinkable.
Bottle.  Browish amber pour with a medium tan head.  Aroma of toffee and caramel.  Taste of malt, chocolate, caramel and brown sugar.  Great full finish.

bottle poured into a shaker has an amber color with a thin white head that fell to froth on the surface. aroma has caramel malt, lightly roasted peat, sweetness, and grains. mouth feel is medium with decent coating and frothing creamy carbonation. flavor is well malted with sweet caramel but also has some richness. hops are towards the bitter side with a little pilsner character. bits of minerals come through and it becomes thicker with a malted finish and sweetness.

UPDATED: SEP 26, 2008 By far, Long Trails best beer.  This "secret beer" or sticke, pours with a voluminous, erotic head and a deep copper, mahogany body.  An appetizing aroma of caramellized malt, smoked meats, and butterscotch define this brew, and the tongue is pleasured by a velvet, buttery palate.  The taste too, is very clean, buttery, and slick, sliding like oil over the tongue and bringing further hints of caramel, butter-toffee, toasted malt, and delicate, discreet hop dryness that make this beer the next best thing to a Dusseldorfer Alt, and the crown jewel of Long Trails brewing acheivements.  I drank this, and all of LTs other beers in a small town called Waitsfield, Vermont, not far from the brewery in Bridgewater Corners.  The setting was perfect: under the stars on a cool summer night camping out in the Green Mountains.

Bottle 12 oz. 08’ camp in Millenockett. Pours deep nut brown with a tan head.  Malts,  bittering hops, steel cut grains.  It has lots of alchol warmth and a slightly astringent bitterness.  Its good at the price but not a fantastic beer.

I sampled this beer from the bottle while in MA.  A good caramel malt aroma with some toasty qualities, and a bit of grainy hops too.  A darker amber or color cover with an average-sized, foamy, off-white head.  Sweet and malty flavor with some lingering bitterness.  Good carbonation and a fuller body style, with good moisture but a dry finish.  A pretty good beer, and a signifcantly higher alcohol concentration than I realized.
dark brown with mild white head.  flavor is heavy on malt with a toasty flavor.  mild hop bitterness, not a bad alt

Bottle. Nice copper color, low tanish head. Malty aroma, nutty, caramel. Flavor is nice but alcohol is too present. Nice malt, with caramel and nuts, a touch more hops than usual for the style, though less than an Uerige. Nice, malty beer but too strong alcohol taste.

At 7%, much stronger than I expected. I found the other LTs in this sixer quite smooth and refreshing. Tho altbiery, this is more like a style of strong something; lager or ale. Candy aroma. Looks like a brown oranger transparent beer, somewhat off pale yellow. Barely any carbonation in the glass. Too much for my girlie taste buds. In your face alt, if that is what it is?  Medicine stronger alky biting finish, does not hide its alky content well. Smell is only value above average. Probably would be liked by the IPA and impy stout lovers.
user_location: Beaver Valley, Beaver County, Pennsylvania, USA

text: Pours amber/red with as mall 1/8 off white head.  Aromas of floral hops dominate.  First taste is way smooth  and much less hoppy than the aroma indicated.  There are a couple of favors at work here that I cannot easily identify.  Is it smoke? Oak chips?  Overall not a bad beer.

A nice middle of the road and easy to drink altbier. Aroma was dark malt and a little fruity. Pour was a nice deep dark amber with a one finger near tan head that left quickly. Taste was nice and full but not very lasting. Mostly dark malt with a thin dark fruit taste coming through the middle. Decent carbonation and wet sticky dark malt finish. First beer from this brewer and am not impressed but not disappointed.
user_location: Moon Twp, suburb of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, USA

text: 12oz Bottle.  Pours a brownish amber color with a off white head.  Aroma of hops.  Strong malt flavor, with a semi caramel flavor.  This beer really surprised me, got a six pack and wasn’t able to rate it the first time since I enjoyed drinking them too much.  Great beer, highly recommended, the best from Long Trail I have experienced.
Amber with almost no head. The aroma is malty and sweet with some dark fruit. But it’s not interesting. Actually this sort of sucks.

355 mL bottle.  Amber-brown with a small, short-lived head, which still manages to leave good lacing.  Malty aroma with American hops, caramel and nuts.  Flavour is the same, with an added earthy tone.  Some hops show up at the end.  Alcohol is well hidden until the beer warms.  Crisp. for such a dark, strong beer.  Nice.

Presentation: It was poured from a brown 12oz. bottle into a pint glass. It had a deep copper color with visible carbonation and nice clarity. The head was thin, light tan in color and faded fast leaving spotty bubbles on top of the liquid. A small amount of lace was left on the glass. The aroma had a sweet malty character with caramel notes and mild hops. On the tongue there is a thick sweet malt presence with sweet biscuit and caramel notes. The sweetness is balanced nicely by a strong herbal and leafy hops that seems to take over by the finish. The finish is slow and the flavor seems to stick on the tongue. It has a medium body with a creamy smooth texture and carbonation is active yet very mild. It is a strong beer with bold flavor. Very well done!
Good beer.  Bottle, amber pour and hardly any head at all.  Yeast, stone fruit, malt and apple cider on the nose.  Flavor is very malty and has a fair hop bite as well.  Creamy and tasty.

Draft at Rupununi’s. My first impression of this beer was that is was all booze and bitter. But by the end of the glass, I found enough malts to believe there were some in the beer. Still, the balance was off. Dark amber body with a short head. The aroma was lightly malty with notes of caramel and bread. Floral hops are more noticable. The flavor is lightly sweet and moderately bitter. Heavy taste of alcohol in the finish along with a lingering bitterness. The medium body has a lively carbonation and a thin texture.

Bottle from 46er3498. Thanks man! Pours a golden amber with a nice lasting head. Aroma of sweet fruit cake, caramel and light hops. Light fruit cake sweetness with a touch of tartness in the finish and a light noticeable alcohol. A nice altbier.
Dark amber with a tan head, well-balanced flavors.  A very surprising treat.
UPDATED: OCT 6, 2008 (Bottle).  Definite green apples aroma.  Nice amber color, small head.  Crisp flavor, malts, apples, some nuts.  A very lengthy balanced finished.  Satisfying ale.
Blarghhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhhh this beer was pretty good I enjoyed it.

UPDATED: JUL 15, 2008 Bottle.  Pours amber with a thick white head.  Aroma of nice sweet malt, flowery hops, light fruits, blackberry jam, and rhubarb.  Yum!  Flavor of sweet light fruits, walnuts, raisin.  Nice and malty.  The body is light and slightly weak, but this beer is quite tasty.  A delicious "session" and a good value beer for its price.
Amber, Malty, bready, sweet, caramel, dark fruits,  with a slight hop finish.
Bottle as a bones from 46er3498, pours attractive ruddy brown with decent cream colored head. Malt and bready nose with flavor to match, along with a bit of caramel. Pretty good stuff.

Pours into the glass a nice copper color with a white head.  Aroma reminds me somewhat of cognac without the sting.  Flavor is sharply sweet at first but with a nice hop resistance.  This is my first altbier to try, but I find the dramatic split between the sweet and the bitter somewhat strange.  Neither really offsets each other, just happens at different times.
bottle, a very solid tasting easy to find beer. A lot of malt but nothing to really balance the malt. Still the malt taste was great. Tasty I like this one a lot I would buy it again
user_location: The World of Beer, Texas, USA

text: Pours a light amber brown.  This is a sweet, malty, smooth, easy to drink brew that is not all that complex. Despite going down easy, I just couldnt get into this beer, perhaps for lack of any hop character or interesting blend.

As soon as I poured it I was excited to taste this beer. The aroma gave a great preview of the flavors that make it tough to put the glass down. The alcohol becomes more apparent as it warms, but it is still easy to finish.

Had at the brewery and it was the best of their line. The aroma was sweet and malty. It was well balanced and a bit creamy on taste and you picked up the carmel again. At the end a little bit of the alcohol came through. I enjoyed this one.
Aroma has a distinct green apple peel element that follows through to a lesser extent in the flavor.  Aside from that slight weirdness, a pretty solid brew.  Good hops and malt balance.

Medium brown pour, with whitish head that leaves very little behind. Sweet aroma, with caramel, cream, vanilla. Mouthfeel is pretty thin for a beer this sweet. Reminded me of a cream soda or malt chocolate drinking it. No hop at all. Decent, but pretty simple beer.

UPDATED: OCT 11, 2008 Medium bodied with a pillowy mouthfeel, Double Bag hides its 7.2 percent alcohol content well. The aroma is malty with touch of candy, dough and raisins. It pours a coppery brown, but lacks any significant head. The first sip starts sweet but ends with a big whack of earthy bitterness that lays on the sides of the tongue producing a long finish. The hops are very subdued in the aroma lending a light metallic quality. Not quite fruity, but not floral either. One of Long Trails more flavorful entries, Double Dag is labelled an altbier, and equally displays its ale-lager heritage.

First thing I noticed was the 7.2% alcohol content.  Pours an almost syrupy texture, amber colored with a thin white head that leaves a little bit of lace.  Very rich malty, spiced taste that stays with you until the spicy hoppy finish.  There isnt a dull moment with this beer.  Good beer.

12oz bottle.  Caramel color in the pour.  Spicy with notes of alcohol.. 7.2 % isnt hidden very well. Finish is astringent. Not great.

Bottle from the Cranium at work.  Nose is sweet and whispy with a tinge of hops after the sweeet malts.  Pours a clear crisp amber with small oily head.  Body is quite light for the 7+%. It certainly doesnt seem that way.  Ill give them balanced but just. Rich malty body, maybe on a Coors standard but not mine. Three generous addition?  Whos making this beer?  Accountants and bean counters.  I thought Yankee generosity was a bit more hospitable than this.  Well fit to stuyle but overhyped.

Poured amber with thin off-white head, caramel nose with little hop aroma.  Flavor has bitterness more prominent than sweetness but caramel malts do provide adequate support.  A bit thin on the tongue. A nice brew, surprisingly easy to drink given the 7.2%.

12 ounce bottle from Glenville beverage. Light brown, didnt get much of a head with this one. This one is malty and has some nice hops. If it were a little sweeter it would remind me of davidson brothers dacker. nice beer.

Amber-brown, slight white head fades quickly to a scum.  Aroma a bit indistinct, very clean: slight floral hops and caramel malt.  Taste is nice, balanced. Grassy, hay and flower notes, caramel, nuts and a touch of toffee.  A touch of sweet fruitiness from the ale yeast. Slight bitter finish and aftertaste, rasping on the tongue.  Full mouthfeel, with moderate carbonation. Alcohol nicely imperceptible. This is a fine beer, very sessionable.

A number of raters focused on the "hidden" character of the alcohol. While I do find the alcohol taste noticeable, I dont necessarily think that is a bad thing. When drinking an alcoholic beverage, I kinda like to know it. That said, there is really nice complexity to this beer that goes beyond the fact that it packs a wallop. I very much enjoy it pre-dinner. Its rather on the rich side, with a nice caramelly sweetness, but not at all cloying. Im a big fan, especially when skiiing/snowboarding in Vermont - in other words, a great winter brew. Best served cool, not cold.
Clear amber. Floral sticky caramel aroma. Clean quality caramel malt flavor with balancing German hops. Low noticeable alcohol. Nice bitterness. Well done.
Smells light and faintly of berries. Tastes nicely malty with a nice balance of bitter and sour hops. The alcohol content is hidden nicely. Very tasty.

Appearance: clear amber, wispy beige head, bits of drippy lace, 
Aroma: sweet caramel malt aroma with a fruity tartness and floral hops, 
Body: creamy body,

Bottle. Pours copper with an off white head. Malty aroma with notes of caramel, hazelnut, and some fruit... cherry maybe? Medium/full body. Very nice malty flavor. Starts with some caramel and chestnut, which give way to dried fruit and roasted malt. Finishes with a nice sweetness and earthy bitterness. 7.2% alcohol isnt noticeable at all. This is a great beer.
Simply put...very tasty!  Enjoy with a bacon and cheddar cheeseburger.  Rewarding at 7.2%

UPDATED: JUL 28, 2008 On tap at the Plan B, West Hartford, CT. Amber body, no head by the time it got to me. Aroma had me worried, pretty weak toast with some hops. Flavor better though, a nice banana taste standing out most after a few sips, backed up by the hops and a good amount of caramel. Mouthfeel a bit weak like the aroma, no staying power. Overall though, a very enjoyable, drinkable brew, and I was surprised to see here that it actually gets up to 7.2%. 5-4-7-3-15/3.4  Rerate 7/28/08. Bottle, 1/08. Aroma of some floral hops, some bordering-on-metallic caramel malt, almost burntish, some tangerine, maybe other similarly-colored fruits. Flavor sweet dough; really interesting malt component to this one. Low carbonation, a touch sticky. Ok. 6-4-7-3-13/3.3
Pours dark amber with average head. Nice hoppy aroma. Flavour is very smooth considering the 7.2 alcohol percetage. Nice malt character- rich and full bodied. Good winter brew.

bottle from alldaydrinker dated 8/17/7. dark copper pour with a decent off white head. malty aroma with earth, spiciness and a lager yeasty aroma. flavor is light caramel malt, herbal spiciness, grassy hops, brown sugar and an unknown fruitiness.  it finishes malty with the alcohol coming in late. lingering hoppy dryness. light to medium bodied but a creamy mouth feel from the carbonation. definitely becomes more robust as it approaches room temperature
Slight vinegar aroma. Clear amber-orange color with not much foam. Tangy cider and yeast flavor.

Some say the flavors of this beer mask the alcohol, but I disagree. This beer has a pretty strong alcohol taste. Aside from that, it smells great and tastes even better. By far my favorite from Long Trail.

Bottle sampled. Pours a dark copper color with a small off-white head. Aroma of toasted malts, caramel, sour dough, and spicy hops. Flavor is caramel malts, citrus, light fruit and finishes with a mild hop bitterness.

Pours out an deep amber color with a slightly reddish hue. Head is thin and white. This beer smells very sweet, perhaps some brown sugar in there as well as some yeasty notes. The taste is incredibly smooth, that was the first thing that I noticed. This beer has a dough-like taste to it mixed with sweet hay from a farm and caramel mixed in. This drinks like a session beer but I notice that it as a decent alcohol kick. Very suprising to read that as the alcohol is hidden incredibly well. Good beer, recomended.

[629-20070917] 12floz. Yeasty bread aroma with light grassy notes. Clear, amber brown body with a quick foamy off-white head. Fairly alcoholic bready dough. Medium body is thick. Mild flavour is good, plus nicely hidden alcohol.

Poured a burnt sienna-amber-copper hue with a medium sized off-white head. Rich malty nose with mild fruity sweetness.  Well hidden alcohol in a spicy, but not overdone hoppy body.  great balance of malts.  Love this style of beer!

12oz bottle.  Pours a clear tan-amber color.  Thick and malty, with a warming crisp flavor.  Rich and big bodied with well defined caramel malt notes.  Moderately hoppy finish, which compliments the sweet malt flavors of the style.
Had it on tap..  It had an amber body, and the flavor was sweet with a hint of caramel.

poured into a dark blue shaker so i couldnt make out the color (boo). initial aroma was sweet fruit (melon), some hay and grass came through with time.  taste - decent malt backbone, some clean caramel,  and a mild/moderate bitter hop.  mild carbonation - nice.  no hint of above ave abv.  i had no idea of style when i got it and the dark pint forced me to rely on taste and aroma alone... the malt profile pointed me toward lager, although the hops come through toward the end had hints of british style pale ale - either way its got some substance.  better than expected from long trail - the blackberry wheat is atrocious and i havent tried another until this.  worth sampling.  wouldnt mind having it again.

Bomber brought back from Vermont by my mom, on her trip east. Received bottle last month, drank last night with dinner. Maybe not the best beer to accompany pasta with sundried tomato basil sauce. Pours deep copper topped with a thick beige foam. Nice retention here as well. Burnt brown sugar in the aroma. Sime bready, yeasty notes follwed by molasses and heavy metallic malts. Pretty sweet caramel malts come first, with a nice hop zip afterwards.Kinda fruity, slightly toasty. FInishes strong with the 7.2% This one is best consumed chilled. Thanks mom!
12 oz bottle.  Clear copper with some bone head.  Caramel and orange with a sweet dustiness.  Taste is crisp apple that fades to lemon pith.  Bits of toffee play off dry bitter greens.

Bottle. Amber body with a small creamy beige head. Mild aroma of toasty malt, light caramel. Similar flavour of toasty malt with light caramel sweetness. Alcohol stays just below the surface while chilled. Average palate. Solid but simple. 7/3/7/3/15
This is part of a beer club. Had only one bottle but was decent for the price. Poured great and had a nice finish. Would do again.

12oz. Bottle:  Aroma is medium sweet.  Smells very malty, with notes of sourdough, bread, and caramel.  Poured copper in color with a small white head that diminished quickly.  Crystal clear.  Sparkling.  Flavor is lightly sweet and lightly bitter.  Tastes very malty with notes of caramel, sourdough, bread, and a hint of cinnamon.  Light to medium body.  Thin, slightly tingly texture.  Average carbonation.  Malty, salty finish.  Overall, good flavor but lacking in body and other elements.

Bottle. Pours warm copper with a white ring of foam. Caramel nose with a spicy, almost minty hop presence. Creamy medium body and moderate carbonation. Sweet caramel taste with a pine-bitter finish. Overall impression is like an imperial pale lager. Nice for a cool afternoon.

UPDATED: JAN 31, 2008 On the label is a silly picture of Vermont cows with their udders hanging down.  Are those beer cows?  Does this beer have milk in it?  Anyway, it is a rich copper brown with a small head, and has an aroma of malt with a little yeast and astringent tang.  The taste is rich and well-rounded: sweet grains, a dash of citrus, and spicy hops in the finish.  Soft and smooth on the palate.  It is nice to see a little European influence  reaching the green hills of Vermont.
Heavy malt, easily hides the alcohol. A bit dry but balanced out with a bit of hops and slight sweetness. Very nicely balanced overall with a nice reddish tinged color.

12 Oz bottle-trade w/mcox90-clear copper color w/a slight head. Sweet, roasted malt aroma. Fresh, clean, crisp  brew, w/traces of roasted malt, cane sugar, almonds, caramel, & dark fruit. Had a nice bitter bite on the back end to balance it out. Long, smooth finish. Easy drinking brew, could easily be a session beer that would get you in trouble as alcohol is well hidden. A definite winner; thanks Mike!

Bottle with a stamped date of 05-30-07.  I dont know it that is a brew date or an expiration date.  Pours a dark copper with an off-white head.  I noticed the malts but not the hops.  Swirls great in my mouth.  Full-bodied flavor.  A nice looking and tasty brew.

12oz bottle. Pours copper color, with  a moderate sized tan head. Sweet, malty aroma with some leather and hops. Big malty flavor, with hops in the finish. Very easy to drink for a 7.2% beer. I used to seek this beer out when i traveled to VT, now Im happy to see its available in my backyard.

Bottle at Bob and Lizs warehouse in NJ on the way back from BCTC this year. Thanks yall!  I always used to secretly rag on this beer..not really sure why, but I was never  a big Long Trail fan (my roomate used to drink Hit the Trail every single night). The reason I metion all this is because this is a pretty darn good beer. Full richly malted body and flavor, notes of dark fruits, cadied sugars, and some very mild hops.  Really on par for the style. Well done, Long Trail!

UPDATED: AUG 25, 2007 Pours a light amber with small, lacy head. Has sweet malt aroma with crisp flowers, slight merlot dryness and mild hops. Tastes of slight tart berry, mild hop bitterness, nutty caramel malts, and a dry wine finish. Great for an altbier.
Beautiful red pour with small white head.  I felt well balanced sweet vs bitter with a taste of caramel, nuts, and a slight apple taste.

12 oz. bottle consumed at fridge temp. Poured a deep golden color with a hint of redness. Small white head. Aroma  and taste was sweet. Caramel and light fruits. No bitterness. Mouth feel was a bit on the heavy side. No aftertaste. A very good brew from Long Trail.

Pours a deep amber with an off-white head.  Aroma is malty and fruity and spicy hops.  Taste is caramel malt giving way to fruity hop bitterness.  Very smooth drinking.  I dont notice the 7.2% alcohol at all.  Great beer.

Draught at Park Ave fest.  Pours deep copper with white head.  The maple sugar was evident, as was some fruity notes.  Unfortunately my tasting was hampered by the plastic cup it was served in, as well as the low 90s degree temps outside.  I will endeavor to retaste under proper conditions.

Pours ruby/brownish with foamy, fading head.  Caramel, roasted sugars, apples for aroma.  Hearty warming beer, with a good dose of rich malts, and a subtle hop tinge.  Light toasted chocolate, sugars, mocha, caramel.  Alcohol is present but well hidden, and provides a warming sensation.  Nice brew

Pours a hazel brown with a thin white head. Nutty, caramel aroma, with flavours to match. A little bit to much malt sweetness with not enough hop to balance the beer, but still an interesting enough beer to keep my attention till the end. Moderate carbonation with medium body suited the beer. All and all not a bad brew but probably wouldnt purchase again, not my style.

Slightly hazed amber body with a small offwhite head. Toasty and nutty caramel aroma on a fruity hop background. Taste follows suit with a subtle fruity hop bitterness mingles with a pleasant caramel and nutty malt backbone. The alcohol is just barely noticed and fits in quite well. Very engaging.

7/16/2007:  Long Trail Double Bag smells sweet and malty with some toast, caramel, and light citrus in the aroma as well.  The color is orang-amber and clear.  A thin, off-white head slowly forms on top as the smooth, mild carbonation bubbles make their way to the surface.  The flavor is rich with toasted caramel malts, mellow hops, and a hint of apples, citrus, and some other vague fruitiness.  There is a long, enjoyable, lightly roasty finish.  This beer has a medium to medium-full body is is very smooth on the palate.  Double Bag is a really good Altbier!  Im glad that I was fortunate enough to receive a bottle.
12 oz bottle (Alcohol content of 7.2%; Bottled on 04/17/06.) from porterhouse.  Thanks Kevin!  Rating #251 for this beer...

Bottle.  Sticke, huh?  Sweetly malty aroma, nutty and caramelly with light toffee and vague fruitiness.  Amber-copper body with medium carbonation and a soapish beige head.  Taste is slickly malty, strongly bitter with occasional flights of fruity, floral sweetness, though with continental hops returning to dominate.  Medium body feels fuller than it is, finishes with a slightly floral but very dry aftertaste.  Straightforward but interesting winner!
One of my favorite beers of the NE.  Nice flavor, very smooth.  Definitely the top Long Trail brew, knocks the socks off their IPA.

12 oz. bottle on 7/7/07. This poured out with a nice yellowish white head over an amber body with fair lace. Aromas of caramel, orange, and some other darker fruits was pretty nice actually. Medium body, light carboantion, and slightly astringent palate. Nice malty sweetness followed by some pepperyy bitterness that led to a dry finish. For some reason, I wasnt expecting much from this beer, but it was actually pretty good.
xxx mmm tasty.  theres cows on the bottle which was pretty cool and drew me to it.  one of my favorite altbiers out there, very good (muy bien)

12oz bottle.  The pour is dark red in a pint glass.  The aroma is like a barley wine with a hint of lemon.  The flavor is malty and tastes a little like maple sugar candy.  The hops and ABV are very present as the beer warms up a bit.  This used to be a super strong beer for me before my ratebeer /beergeek days.    This is Long Trails most interesting and most balanced beer.  I think that this is the only "altbier" that I have had, so I should try a few more.
Bottle. Pours an deep orange amber body with thin head. aroma is of malt, light fruitiness. Flavor is slightly bitter, malty, an odd fruitiness. A little syrupy thick mouthfeel.

This one is a sleeper. 
 Pours a dark copper appearance with a quick beige disappearing head. Strong malt presence and an upfront, sweet hoppy backbone give a  pleasant buzz. This deserves a repeat visit.

Not to familiar with this style.  Clear amber body with a slightly off-white head which had some retention.  Aroma was very malty with mainly a caramel and some more earthy notes.  Flavor was mildly balanced.

Sparkling Amber color.  Head quickly disappeared and left nice light carbonation.  It has a pleasant blend of malts and hops.  After an afternoon of drinking Captain and Cokes, this is a great first beer for the night.  I can imagine sipping this beer sitting in the garden.  It didnt leave any lasting nasty feeling on my palate.  Overall a good beer for an early summers evening.

Cold 12oz bottle:  Pours a crystal clear sunset orange color with a thin layer of alabaster bubbles, mostly around the edges.  Aroma is of malt, flowers, grass and notes of alcohol.  Taste is of malt and well blended hops with hints of citrus and caramel.  Light to medium bodied with moderate carbonation.  Ending is of subtle hops and malt with a slight alcohol burn.

A clear dark gold brew with a quick fading off-white head. The strong malt flavor comes through first followed by a gentle hop finish. Definitely full bodied and yet smooth. I too was fooled by the high abv. I had to have a second bottle; and then cancelled my evening drive.
(Bottle)  Pours a clear copper with medium creamy off-white head.  Aroma of caramel, Peeps Easter candy, toasted malt, and honey.  Flavor of caramel, nuts, and mild hops.

bottle . . pours dark redish copper with a light white head . . aroma is grass, hops, malts, honey and toasted marshmellows . . taste is sweet hops, caramel, citrus, very fresh tasting . . nice finish! . . deffinently best long trail offering . . very much enjoyed it . . very clean and refreshing

Double Bag is a clear, light brown ale with a small, fluffy white head.  The aroma is of noble hops-- soft and fruity.  Its medium-bodied and soft and fluffy on the tounge.  The flavor is soft fruity bitterness.  Yum!  This beer is smooth and of substance.
On tap @ Coles Buffalo Ny. The best beer from Long Trail to date. Creamy full bodied & well balanced. Up there with Dead Guy in terms of Maibocks
bottle. light head, whiff of sweetness in the aroma. tastes of malts with a very bitter aftertaste and a hint of something else i cant quite place as it warms. ok beer.

2005 bomber from styles (looks like it was originally from EDA).  Poured a slightly hazy deep amber with a very nice cap of off-white head.  The aroma opened up well as the brew warmed up... sweet caramel accented by grassy and herbal hops.. sweet.  The flavor picked up a sweet candy and caramelly base with an array of complimentary hoppage (grassy, citrus, and herbal notes come through)... something spicy accents the finish well.  Almost syrupy on the palate with herbal bitterness and a mild roast spreading outward.. some overt alcohol flavors and warmth, but didnt detract much.  Tasty and enjoyable brew.
This is a full bodied ale that has a nice amount of hops and malt.  Layers of clove make this an interesting finish.
Full body but a light, tart head masks the alcohol content. Quite the brew!
I BOUGHT IT AND DRANK IT FOR AWHILE. MAYBE CAUSE THERE WERE SOME  GRAY DAYS AND I NEEDED SOME CANDY...WITH A KICK. HEY. THEY HIDE THE 7.2 WELL!

Gets a four for appearence partially because of the deleightful picture of two cows on the bottle. Pretty light amber color though, with a relatively thick long standing head. Fruity and sweet aroma, nothing special per se there. The beer itself is light at the front and leads to expectations that the remainder of the sip will follow in suit, but it certainly does not. The finish become thick and syrupy and finishes off with a bitter aftertaste, with a few other tastes that I could not quite pin point.
Poured into a pint glass, clear amber colour. Moderate size head, light body, smooth,fair lacing, head mostly lasting. Slightly malty,grassy aftertaste. Has a great refreshing appearance and taste.

This beer was poured into a pint glass with a moderate head to it. The smell was very intence with malt and fruit and a toffee. It had a nice copper color when poured out and the booze could be tasted a bit but it was still smooth to drink and refreshing after a long hard day of work.
Slightly malty, orange-y, nice mouth feel. As other posters have noted, high alcohol content is invisible to the palate. Overall a very pleasant beer, one I would drink again.

Pours a clear orange coppery color with a small white head.  Aroma of caramel,toffee and orange peel.  Taste is slightly bitter with hints of orange malty flavor.  Very drinkable and quite refreshing.

A very nice beer. Very thick and has a great taste. Goes down very smooth and the after taste is nice. The alcohol content is high and after two or three you are set. A very nice beer but I cant find it in California.

Bottle. Red-brown colour. Aroma of roasted sweet malts and alcohol with a good touch of sweetness. Flavour is bitter-sweet with roasted malts, good hoppiness, long aftertaste. A nice and warming tasty brew!
had this beer a few nights ago,, quite good buttery malt taste. could not really get a hint of that 7.2 percent alcohol. played beerpong with it and it was tolerable.

Deep ruby-brown colour with a thin white head. Aroma is of fruit and grass. The texture is slick and sticky and the carbonation is perfect. The booze is masked very well. The taste has a solid malt body with some hints of carmel, banana, and smoke. Slightly bitter aftertaste. An enjoyable, easy-drinking  beer I would buy again.
UPDATED: SEP 24, 2007 Bottle.  A very well balanced alt.  Caramel color, somewhat smokey with a huge amount of hops.  Awesome stuff.

Sweet caramel, but also a good bit of smoke.  Green apples.  Probably the most accurate toffee flavor Ive ever found in a beer.  A bit of butter, but not overwhelming or harmful.  Almost a sticky sweetness.  Some noble hop flavor.  A little metallic as they can be, but not too much.  Definitely the best beer these guys make.  Very complex and rich.  Nice beer

12 oz bottle.  Seen this one on the shelf for a while now, and finally got a sixer to try out.  Copper/amber clear, with light off-white head.  Not a lot of nose to speak of, but it is smooth and easy to drink.  Sweet, light carmel flavor, hoppy and not bitter.  Dont know if Ill buy another 6-pack but will enjoy this one while Ive got it.
Bottle.  Soapy green grass aroma.  Dark amber color with moderate head.  Slightly sweet malt with moderate hops.  Light body.  Not much to it.

Alts are rarely great, but often enjoyable. This is no exception. Solidly sweet malt body supports a strong hop profile that make this well rounded. The 7.2% ABV isnt terribly high, but youd never guess it was over 5%.

Ski weekend in Vermont = trying some different Long Trail beers.  Vermont doesnt have much, but they do have the Double Bag.  Amber color with medium head.  Caramel malts mix well with an almost candy-like sweet aroma.  Taste is very sweet with some fruit flavors mixed in.  Pretty good hop profile that makes this one very drinkable.  Interesting - nice brew from a fairly average brewery.

Aroma is rich caramel, a tad smokey, and has a little over-ripe fruit with a woody hop background. Flavor is heavily malty with a touch of fruitiness but not in the estery ESB way-it is very rich like dried dates-as well as having strong woody bitter finish which is a tad overpowering.
